key_title: Key to the species of Erodium

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Geraniaceae

source.author: Smith, L.P.; Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Geraniaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Smith, L.P.; Walsh, N.G. (1999). Geraniaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves ovate-cordate, entire or shallowly 5–7-lobed; stylar column to 3 cm long in fruit
Leaves distinctly lobed to pinnate; stylar column longer than 3 cm in fruit
Leaves lobed to deeply pinnatifid (i.e. with wings of tissue along rachis connecting adjacent lobes), or sometimes with 3 distinct leaflets; petals blue or pink
Leaves pinnate (i.e. divided into distinct leaflets, without a wing of connecting tissue along rachis) with more than 3 leaflets; petals white or pink
Indumentum of calyx (and usually pedicels) mostly glandular; largest leaves with more than 3 lobes
Indumentum of calyx and pedicel entirely or mostly eglandular; largest leaves usually 3-lobed to trifoliolate
Pits on mericarp at base of awns deep, glabrous, divided by 2 or more acute or narrowly winged papery folds; awn usually longer than 8.5 cm

Pits on mericarp at base of awns shallow, hirsute (but sometimes with very few hairs), undivided (or sometimes with an indistinct lower depression), with an obtuse to acute lower margin; awn less than 8.5 cm long
Pits on mericarp at base of awn lacking glandular hairs; leaves (including petiole) usually much less than 10 cm, with deeply pinnatisect leaflets
Pits on mericarp at base of awn with glandular hairs; leaves (including petiole) usually longer than 10 cm, with toothed leaflets
